citations.narrative:
***During exhibition at the Espresso Exotic Animal Expo 10/28/2023 in Dandridge, TN USDA observed a serval in a chain
link kennel with an air kennel/crate provided for the serval inside of the enclosure. The front open side of the kennel was
facing the public and there were no blind spots or hiding spots provided that would allow the serval to get out of the public
eye. The serval was observed continually pacing in the enclosure and entering the crate scratching from side to side at
the interior back side of it. The serval appeared to be exhibiting signs of discomfort or distress. USDA discussed the
abnormal behavior with the licensee and the need to alleviate the servals' discomfort such as providing a means for the
serval to get out of public view or removing it from the exhibit.
USDA returned to the expo on Sunday 10/29/2023 and found the serval in the same condition. The air kennel/crate had
been turned around and brought to the front of the enclosure but the serval was now pacing at the back of the kennel
again showing signs of distress. There were no other structures or blinds provided to shield the serval from the public eye.
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause
behavioral stress or unnecessary discomfort.
Correct by October 30, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Direct
   
Handling of animals. 
***During exhibition at the Espresso Exotic Animal Expo 10/28/2023 in Dandridge, TN USDA observed a serval in a chain 
link kennel with an air kennel/crate provided for the serval inside of the enclosure. The front open side of the kennel was 
facing the public and there were no blind spots or hiding spots provided that would allow the serval to get out of the public 
eye. The serval was observed continually pacing in the enclosure and entering the crate scratching from side to side at 
the interior back side of it. The serval appeared to be exhibiting signs of discomfort or distress. USDA discussed the 
abnormal behavior with the licensee and the need to alleviate the servals' discomfort such as providing a means for the 
serval to get out of public view or removing it from the exhibit. 
 
USDA returned to the expo on Sunday 10/29/2023 and found the serval in the same condition. The air kennel/crate had 
been turned around and brought to the front of the enclosure but the serval was now pacing at the back of the kennel 
again showing signs of distress. There were no other structures or blinds provided to shield the serval from the public eye. 
 
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause 
behavioral stress or unnecessary discomfort. 
 
Correct by October 30, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
